comment.author: 30687643@N00
comment._content: As a Glaswegian living in Ireland I'd love to know why there was a need for a passenger service from Waterford to Glasgow. Was it trade or emigration (quite a circuitous way to get to the UK though)

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Before the railways were built that would have been the fastest way to get from the south coast to Scotland. I wouldn't have thought they'd have got much custom in 1910 though.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: One thing Glassgow would have had in 1910 that perhaps Waterford and the surrounding areas wouldn't have had was jobs !! And as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02]  said the sea route would have been the fastest way for the men to get there and back to their families.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Gorgeous Clyde Shipping Co. poster from ofarrl's photostream...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Mind you, this bunch are all kitted out in tweeds as if they're going shooting or golfing (or both). It doesn't look like either working in the mill clothes or sunday best.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content:
You certainly get the impression that these guys were not your common labours, indeed that guy in the middle seems to have enough infulance to be able to take his dog along LOL.

Bowler hat usually meant manager ......

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Or could he/she have been the ship's dog? Haven't done close up anatomical examination...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38915126@N06
comment._content: Wonderful image and capture.

comment.author: 69751036@N08
comment._content: The guy in the back left has a cigarette in his hand, makes a changes from the pipes.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] I'll leave the sexing to you ;-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Not a sentence one hears every day of the week at Library Towers!  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 45282459@N02
comment._content: It's either a Russell Terrier or a Rat Terrier.  Great dog for a ship to keep stow away rats at bay.

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: Hmmm looking in street view you can't see the clock tower from the Adelphi Quay, anyone with local knowledge know better?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I doubt if this was taken from the Adelphi quay, looks more like the view from Meaghers Quay. This is a photo from a little further down the Quay near the Post Office flic.kr/p/6ExALa

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is about where I think the photo would have been taken, Meaghers Quay (On the Ordnance Survey map it is marked Coal quay) The mooring hulks have all been removed but they were still there up until the 80's I think.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Better? That's what I get for thinking I know my Quays. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/shanekillen] Should have realised Adelphi Quay was way too far away to have that view of the clock tower - sorry!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/47290943@N03] much better:) It would not have been too far from the Clydes offices on the Quay

comment.author: 44113500@N03
comment._content: Those are some epic moustaches!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/44113500@N03] Fairly epic, but not a patch on these ones...

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content:
These photos are so full of fascinating detail! I notice the man on the right at the back is wearing a signet ring, which I've always thought of as a kind of upper-class thing. He's also wearing a ferocious amount of heavy tweed AND carrying  a coat. It's JULY, man!! What on earth would he wear in the winter? Oooo, sailing ship in the background. 

I also noticed in passing that the terrier is male.

comment.author: 99646216@N00
comment._content: Just spotted that the man on the left in the back is wearing plus-fours, you can see his stockings.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Some blokes are wearing masonic ties www.freemasonstore.com/p17912/Navy-&-Light-Blue-Mason...

comment.author: 29492435@N02
comment._content: LOL, Also should have known you wouldn't get away with any "mistakes" in here :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/hockadilly] In passing, eh?  :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] No, afraid not! Checked original at super duper high res (technical term).  Pattern on our gent front right is a triangle surrounded by 3 dots. Shame, that would've been great...

comment.author: 54708393@N08
comment._content: Unusually dusty/dirty shoes for gents of this era.I wonder what they had been up to?.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/54708393@N08] It was July, and maybe back then it didn't rain every day during the summer? I'd imagine the quays would have been a fairly dusty environment...

(Laughing away to myself here, because by morning one of you'll have proved that they worked in a nearby flour mills - but I'm sticking with dusty summer roads)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Photo was definitely taken on teh Clyde Wharf directly opposite the Custom House in Waterford on the eponymous Custom House Quay
